Chapter 5, Section 5: On Action, Part 5. The sÅ«tras say there are three munis, and the sÅ«tras say there are three purities, all of which are of body, speech, and mind.
What are their characteristics?
Verse:
The bodily and verbal actions of the post-learner are the three munis of mind;
The three purities should be known as the three kinds of excellent conduct.
The treatise says:

The bodily action of the post-learner is called the muni of the body, the verbal action of the post-learner is called the muni of speech, and the post-learner's mind itself is called the muni of mind.
The muni of mind is not taken as having the mental action as its essence.
Why is it that only in the form and consciousness aggregates are there munis, and not in the other aggregates?
Some other masters say:
Citing the last and the first, it is to illustrate that the middle also has this meaning.
According to the true meaning, the ultimate muni takes the mind alone as its essence. Therefore the sÅ«tras say:
Because the mind is tranquil, sentient beings are tranquil.
This mind of the Muni, because it is free from evil through bodily and verbal actions, can be inferred.
Mental action is not able to be inferred in the middle, only the inferred and the inferring are combined to establish the Muni.
Why is the Muni only in the state of no-more-learning?
Because the arhat is the true Muni, because the words of the afflictions are eternally tranquil.
The three kinds of excellent conduct of body, speech, and mind are called the three kinds of purity of body, speech, and mind.
Because uncontaminated excellent conduct is eternally free from the defilements of evil conduct and afflictions, it can be called purity.
How can contaminated excellent conduct, which is still defiled by the stains of evil conduct and afflictions, be pure?
This is also called purity because it is temporarily able to be free from the stains of evil conduct and afflictions.
Or, because this power is able to induce the ultimate purity of the uncontaminated, it is given the name purity.

If you say that it is also able to induce the defilements, because it is the condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent of the defilements, then it should not be called pure. This is also unreasonable.
When a good mind arises, it is not because a defiled mind has generated effort. Therefore, a pure mind does not arise immediately after a defiled mind.
Because a good mind that is impure is able to induce a pure mind, good that is impure is called pure, because it is in conformity with a pure mind and is able to eliminate impurity.
The reason for explaining these two is to cause sentient beings to cease to imagine that there is a wrong Muni and a wrong purity.
Also, a scripture says that there are three kinds of bad conduct, and it says that there are three kinds of good conduct, all of which are of body, speech, and mind.
What are their characteristics?
The verses of Vasubandhu say:
The three kinds of bad conduct are said to be bad conduct of body, speech, and mind.
The three kinds of good conduct are the opposite of these.
The verses of Sanghabhadra say:
The preparatory and subsequent actions of all unwholesome bodily and verbal actions, as well as the unwholesome volition itself, are respectively called bodily, verbal, and mental evil conduct.
However, mental evil conduct is of three kinds: non-mental action, greed, anger, and wrong views.
Isn't it also said in the scriptures that greed, etc. are called mental actions? How can it be said now that greed, anger, and wrong views are not mental actions?
Because they are the provisions for action, they are also called action, just as the provisions for defilements are also called defilements, etc.
Because they are despised and condemned by all sages and saints, and because they can lead to undesirable consequences, these practices are evil, and therefore called evil conduct.
The three good practices should be understood in the opposite way.
That is, the preparatory and subsequent actions of all wholesome bodily and verbal actions, as well as the wholesome volition itself, are respectively called bodily, verbal, and mental good conduct.
However, mental good conduct is of three kinds: non-action, non-greed, non-anger, and right views.
Because it is praised by the wise, and because it produces a beloved fruit, this action is called good.
Even though right view and wrong view do not benefit or harm others, they are the roots of good and evil and therefore are also good and evil.
Also, a scripture says:
There are ten courses of action that are either good or evil.
What are their characteristics?
A verse says:
The ten courses of action are included in evil and good conduct,
And their natures are the gross and obvious, which are good or evil as appropriate.
The treatise says:
Among the good and evil conduct mentioned above, if they are gross, obvious, and easy to understand, they are included in the ten courses of action.
As appropriate, if they are good, they include the good conduct mentioned above; if they are evil courses of action, they include the evil conduct mentioned above.
What kinds of good and evil conduct are not included?
The preparatory and subsequent actions, etc., because they are not gross and obvious.

As for the ten evil paths of action, if bodily evil actions cause sentient beings to lose their lives, lose their wealth, lose their wives and concubines, etc., they are called paths of action, in order to make one stay far away from them.
If verbal evil actions have even more serious faults, they are called paths of action, in order to make one stay far away from them.
If mental evil actions are heavy greed, anger, etc., they are called paths of action, in order to make one stay far away from them.
The preliminary actions, subsequent actions, and other minor faults, as well as unwholesome volition, are all not paths of action.

As for the good paths of action, the good bodily path of action does not include one part of good bodily action, namely the preliminary actions, subsequent actions, and other good bodily actions, such as abstaining from alcohol, cutting grass, and giving alms, etc.
The good verbal path of action does not include one part of good verbal action, namely affectionate speech, etc.
The good mental path of action does not include one part of good mental action, namely wholesome volition.
Are the first seven paths of action all definitely with both indication and non-indication?
No, it is not so.
What is the meaning of this?
A verse says:
The six evil paths are definitely without expression, and if one does it oneself, there are two in sexual misconduct.
The seven good paths are born from receiving, and there are two in the two meditations. In the meditations, there is only the inexpressible.
The treatise says:
Among the seven evil paths of action, the six are definitely without expression, namely killing and so forth, except for sexual misconduct.
This is not like the six, if one sends another to do it, when one reaches the fundamental time, there is the arising of expression.

If there is one who does these six paths of action oneself, then the six all have both expression and the inexpressible. This is because when one gives rise to expression, they immediately die and so forth, and later they die and so forth, the same as sending an emissary. When the fundamental is accomplished, there is only the inexpressible.
There is only sexual misconduct, which must be of two kinds, because it is what is completed by one's own body. It is not like sending another to do it, giving rise to joy like oneself.
The seven good paths of action, if born from receiving, must all be of two kinds, namely expression and the inexpressible. This is because the precepts born from receiving must rely on expression.
Restraint that is included in the realm of form and the formless realm is called that which arises from samÄdhi. It is only non-manifest action, because it only arises through the power of the mind.
Are the preparatory and subsequent actions the same as the fundamental action?
No, it is not so.
How is it?
The verse says:
The preparatory action definitely has manifest action, but non-manifest action may or may not exist.
The subsequent action is the opposite of this.
The treatise says:

The preparatory action of the karmic paths definitely has manifest action. Non-manifest action may or may not exist in this stage. If it arises from intense entanglements and pure mind, then there is non-manifest action. Otherwise, there is none.

The subsequent action is the opposite of the above. It definitely has non-manifest action. The beginning of non-manifest action in the second moment is called subsequent action. Therefore, it definitely exists.
If one gives rise to it according to the previous action, then it also has manifest action. Otherwise, it does not exist.

In this meaning, the different characteristics of the preparatory, fundamental, and subsequent actions of establishing the karmic paths should be known as extensively explained in the Saá¹ƒyuktÃ¢bhidharmahá¹›daya.
Also, a scripture says:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know that killing has three kinds: one arising from greed, one arising from anger, and one arising from delusion.
Up to wrong views having three kinds is also like this.
How can it be that at the time of completion of the courses of action, all are due to the three roots?
The Buddha's statement is not that at the time of completion of the courses of action, all are due to the three roots, but that there are differences in the preparatory stages.
What are the differences?
Verse:
The preparatory stages arise from the three roots, because they immediately give rise to those.
Arising from the three roots of greed, etc.
Commentary:
When the preparatory stages of the unwholesome courses of action arise, each arises from the three unwholesome roots. This is said based on their original instigation.

The preparatory stage of killing arising from greed is like having greed for their teeth, hair, or body parts, or in order to obtain wealth, or for the sake of amusement, or in order to rescue a friend or oneself, one gives rise to the preparatory stage of killing out of greed.
That which arises from hatred is like the case of one who, in order to eliminate an enemy, gives rise to an angry mind and performs the action of killing.
That which arises from delusion is like the case of the Persians who say:

If one causes oneâ€™s aged and sick parents to end their lives, one then produces superior merit, because one causes them to be liberated from present suffering and to obtain a new, superior body with sharp faculties.
Also, they say that killing in a sacrifice to the Dharma is permissible.
Also, kings and others, in accordance with worldly law, punish enemies and execute criminals, and they consider that they thereby produce great merit and perform the action of killing.
Also, non-Buddhists say that snakes, scorpions, bees, and others that are poisonous and harmful to humans should be killed, and that one thereby obtains merit.
Also, sheep, deer, oxen, and other animals are originally intended for food, so there is no sin in killing them.
Also, because of wrong views, one kills living beings.
These actions of killing that are performed as a consequence of these views all arise from delusion.
The remaining six actions of killing arise from the three roots of goodness and evil, as is extensively explained in the Treatise on the Correctness of the Principles .
How can the actions of killing, etc., that arise from greed, etc., arise from the three roots?
Because they are produced immediately after the three roots.
That is, immediately after the three unwholesome roots of greed, etc., each of the three karmic paths is produced.
By this, it is already shown that the three preparatory actions are produced immediately after greed, hatred, and delusion, and the karmic paths are also produced by the meaning of immediately after.
The unwholesome has already been explained as arising from the three roots.
How about the wholesome?
Verse:
In the three stages, all are produced by the three roots of wholesomeness.
Treatise:

The preparatory, fundamental, and subsequent actions of all wholesome karmic paths are produced by the roots of wholesomeness of non-greed, non-hatred, and non-delusion, because the three stages of wholesomeness are all produced by wholesome thoughts, and wholesome thoughts must be associated with the three roots of wholesomeness.
What are the characteristics of these three stages of wholesomeness?
It is said that the three stages of wholesomeness are far removed from the three stages of unwholesomeness, and the three stages of wholesomeness should be known.

For example, when a novice monk receives full ordination, he enters the ordination platform, pays homage to the bhiká¹£u assembly, sincerely speaks and requests the preceptor, up to the first announcement, second announcement, and the three karman procedures, all of which are called the preparatory stages of the good karmic paths.
At the end of the third karman procedure, the manifest and unmanifest actions in one moment are called the fundamental karmic paths.
From then on, up to the recitation of the four refuges and the other dependent and concomitant manifest and unmanifest actions, are all called the subsequent actions.
As explained above, not all karmic paths are completed by the three roots. One should explain by which roots which karmic paths are completed.
The verse says:ğŸ”½Killing, harsh speech, and malice are all completed by hatred.
Stealing, sexual misconduct, and greed are all completed by greed.
Wrong views are completed by delusion. The remaining ones are said to be completed by the three.
The treatise says:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
In the evil destinies, the destinies of killing, harsh speech, and anger are completed by hatred. When the mind is extremely cruel and evil, these three are completed.
The three destinies of taking what is not given, sexual misconduct, and greed are completed by greed. When the mind is extremely defiled, these three are completed.
Wrong views are completed only by delusion, because they are completed by the manifestation of intense delusion.

The three destinies of false speech, divisive speech, and frivolous speech are each allowed to be completed by the three [roots]. Because when greed, hatred, etc. manifest, each can cause these three to be completed.
Where do the various evil destinies arise?
In verse, it is said:
Sentient beings, form, name, and name-body, etc. arise in these places.
In the treatise, it is said:
As explained above, the four categories of destinies arise in the four places of sentient beings, etc., in order.

The three of killing, stealing, and sexual misconduct arise in the realm of sentient beings, because these karmic paths arise in dependence on sentient beings. Therefore, they do not arise in dependence on external objects alone.
Arenâ€™t these three also called arising in the realm of form?
One aggregate and one moment can also be called form. These three are called form because they rely on the general characteristics of the aggregates.

The three of stealing, sexual misconduct, and covetousness arise in the realm of the possessions of others. When one desires to appropriate the possessions of others, the karmic path is then accomplished.
Although they depend on sentient beings, the possessions are superior. Therefore, it is said that the three are accomplished in dependence on possessions.
Only wrong views are called arising in the realm of name and form, because they deny the existence of name and form.

Although they also deny nirvÄá¹‡a as nonexistent, they deny eternal cessation through the door of name and form. They say, â€œThere is not even suffering, let alone the nirvÄá¹‡a of suffering.â€ Therefore, it is said that they arise in the realm of name and form.
Donâ€™t wrong views also deny the existence of sentient beings? Why is it only said that they arise in the realm of name and form?
Because of this, the name-and-form that is the support is born. If one denies the sentient beings that are the supported, the denial of the provisional is accomplished without being mentioned.
Also, in the holy teachings there is no sentient being, and in principle there is definitely no name-and-form either. The same applies to sentient beings.

Denying the real as nonexistent is serious and thus constitutes an immediate karmic retribution. Denying the nonexistent provisional is light and thus is not an immediate karmic retribution. Therefore it is not said that it occurs in the realm of sentient beings.
The three, such as false speech, etc., occur in the realm of name, etc., because the substance of speech definitely arises in dependence on name, etc.
Although speech also arises in dependence on sentient beings, etc., it directly and closely arises in dependence on name, etc.
Also, frivolous speech does not depend on sentient beings, and there is none that does not depend on name, etc.
Or, it is not a mistake to establish the immediate karmic retribution in dependence on the uncommon realm.

Although coarse speech arises in dependence on name, etc., fearing that it would be said that this immediate karmic retribution is accomplished only in dependence on the external, it is said that it only occurs in the realm of sentient beings.
Also, coarse speech does not require the adornment of words, and therefore it is not said that it arises in dependence on name, etc.
By what is the path of action of killing established?
It is said that it is established by the preparatory action and by the completion of the result. If either of these two parts is missing, one does not incur the fundamental transgression of killing.
Can there be a killer who performs the preparatory action of killing and brings the result to completion, yet who does not incur the transgression of killing?
It is said that there can be.
How is that?
A verse says:
If they die together or before, there is no offense due to the difference in basis.
The treatise says:

If the killer performs the preparatory action of killing with the definite intention to kill another, but dies either at the same time as the being to be killed or before, that killer does not establish the path of action.
Why is that?ğŸ”½Because the life of the being to be killed has not yet been cut off.
Because the life of the killer has already ended and a different basis has arisen.

The body that is the basis of the preparatory action of killing has already been destroyed. Even if a body of the same type is born, it is not the basis of the offense. This [body] has never performed the preparatory action of killing. It is not reasonable that it should complete the path of action of killing.
If many people gather to form an army, wishing to kill enemies or hunt animals, when one of them kills, which person completes the path of killing?
The verse says:
If in the army and so forth they act together, all complete it like the one who acts.
The treatise says:ğŸ”½If in the army and so forth, if one person performs the act of killing, all complete the path of killing like the one who acts, because they agree to do it for one purpose.
Just as for one purpose they mutually instruct each other, therefore when one kills, the others all incur the offense.

If another person is forced into this situation, the one who causes it will also incur the sin of killing, except if the person has made a vow to save his own life and does not kill even in this situation, because he has no intention to kill and therefore does not incur the sin of killing.
Now we should separately discuss the characteristics of the ten kinds of evil deeds. What is the extent of killing?
Up to what extent is it called wrong views?
First, we will distinguish the characteristics of killing. The verse says:
Killing is due to intentional thought, the thought of another, not mistakenly killing.
The treatise says:

It is necessary to first give rise to the intention to kill, to have the thought of other sentient beings, to carry out the act of killing, and not to mistakenly kill. This means only killing that person and not mistakenly killing someone else. This is called the karmic path of killing.
Some have doubts, thinking it might be a stump or a person.
Even if it is a person, is it that person or not?

Therefore, if one gives rise to a resolute intention, whether it is true or not, I will definitely kill. Due to the mind being without regard, if one kills sentient beings, one also completes the karmic path.
In this way, if the karmic path is definite or doubtful, but one possesses the conditions for killing, all have a principle of completion.
How is the sin of killing established in the momentary cessation of action?

By giving rise to an evil mind and performing the preparatory action of killing, when the life of the one to be killed is presently extinguished, it cannot serve as a cause to attract a similar life. It obstructs the life that should arise, causing it to never arise. Therefore it is called killing, and one obtains the sin due to this.
Having already distinguished killing, one should discuss taking what is not given.
Verse:
Taking what is not given is taking another's property by force or stealth, making it one's own.
Treatise:
The previous words without error and so forth should flow to the following as appropriate.

That is, one must first arouse the intention to steal, think of anotherâ€™s property as anotherâ€™s, either by force or stealth, arouse the activity of stealing, and take it without error and make it oneâ€™s own. This is called the sin of taking what is not given.
If one steals property from a stupa, one commits an offense against the Buddha, because when the Buddha is about to enter nirvana, he accepts in general all the property given to him by the world.

If one steals property belonging to the Saá¹…gha that has already been distributed, one commits the sin of stealing from the Saá¹…gha within the boundary. If the distribution has not been completed, one commits the sin of stealing from the entire Saá¹…gha.
If one steals anotherâ€™s elephants, horses, etc., one commits the sin of stealing when they leave the place where they belong.
Having explained taking what is not given, we will now explain sexual misconduct.
A verse says:
Sexual misconduct is of four kinds, engaging in what should not be engaged in.
The treatise says:
In general, there are four kinds of engaging in what should not be engaged in, all of which are called the sin of sexual misconduct.
First, with regard to a non-object, that is, one who is protected by others, whether mother, father, parents' relatives, or even one who has lost the protected object.
Second, with regard to a non-path, that is, even one's own wife, by mouth or other paths.
Third, with regard to a non-place, that is, in a stupa, a temple, or an open place.
Fourth, with regard to a non-time, that is, when pregnant, when nursing, or when observing precepts.
Some say that if a husband has agreed to observe precepts but violates them, it is considered a non-time.

Since it is not a mistake in speech, it also falls into this category.ğŸ”½If with regard to another's wife one thinks it is one's own wife, or with regard to one's own wife one thinks it is another's wife, or with regard to the path or non-path, etc., one only has a mistaken mind, then even if one engages in it, it is not a karmic path.

If with regard to another's wife one thinks of another's wife, and engages in impure conduct, some say it is also accomplished, because the preparation and enjoyment are both with regard to another's object.
Some say: Just as the path of action of killing is not completed, because the prior object and the subsequent object are different.
Bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s and others who have the wife of a monk, if they are violated, also complete the path of action.
Having explained sexual misconduct, we will now explain false speech.
Verse:
With defilement, a different thought, uttering speech, understanding the meaning, is false speech.
Treatise:
Because of the power of speaking and listening, false speech is completed.

It is said: Speaking with a different thought regarding what is spoken, and the deceived person understanding the meaning of what is spoken, with a defiled mind and without error, only then does it become a path of action.
If the deceived person has not yet understood, it is included in frivolous speech.
Speech is composed of many syllables. The manifest and unmanifest actions of the final moment only then become a path of action.
Or, it is completed as soon as the deceived person understands the meaning.
The syllables that accompany the previous speech are all the preparation for this.
Here, understanding the meaning refers to the deceived person being able to understand, called understanding, not correctly understanding the meaning.
Up to what point is it called being able to understand and correctly understand?
The former refers to the understanding that occurs when the ear consciousness is present;
the latter refers to the correct discrimination of the meaning.

If the correct understanding of the meaning is known by the mental consciousness, and the verbal expression is simultaneously extinguished with the ear consciousness, then this karmic path would only be accomplished by the non-manifest.

Therefore, it is reasonable that when a person of good understanding speaks, the karmic path is accomplished by the ear consciousness, because the one who deceives is endowed with both the manifest and non-manifest [forms of the karmic path].
Some say that the deceived person accomplishes the karmic path according to whether they understand or do not understand the deception, but only if there is a different intention.

Otherwise, this would be the same as divisive speech, and it would only be accomplished if the other person accepts it or not.ğŸ”½The sÅ«tras say that there are generally sixteen kinds of speech. That is, in regard to things that are not seen, not heard, not sensed, and not cognized, to say that one truly sees them, etc., and in regard to things that are seen, etc., to say that one does not see them, etc. These eight kinds are called non-holy speech.

In regard to things that are not seen, etc., to say that one does not see them, etc., and in regard to things that are seen, etc., to say that one truly sees them, etc. These eight kinds are called holy speech.
What are the characteristics of what is seen and so forth?
Verse:
By means of the eye, ear, mental consciousness, and the other three, what is directly experienced,
Is respectively called what is seen, heard, cognized, and known.
Commentary:
If an object is directly experienced by the eye, ear, mental consciousness, or the other consciousnesses, it is respectively called what is seen and so forth.

Because the nose, tongue, and body faculties take objects that are in contact, they are collectively called what is cognized. Other sÅ«tras definitely say that what is taken by the three faculties is what is cognized.
A sÅ«tra says:
Elder sister!
What do you think?

If there is any form that is not seen by your eye, was not seen, will not be seen, and is not sought to be seen, would you give rise to desire, give rise to craving, give rise to affection, give rise to attachment, give rise to a storehouse consciousness, give rise to a foundation of clinging, and give rise to obsession because of this?
No, Venerable One!
Elder sister!
All sounds are not heard by your ears, and so on, up to all dharmas are not cognized by your mind, and so on. This is not so.
Venerable One!
He further told MahÄprajÄpatÄ«:
You should know that what is seen here is only what is seen, you should know that what is heard, cognized, and known is only what is heard, cognized, and known.
Since this sÅ«tra says that form, sound, and dharmas are what is seen, heard, and known, it is determined that what is cognized is the same for the rest.
If this is not accepted, what is cognized?
Also, with regard to the three objects of smell, etc., apart from what is seen, etc., one should not give rise to speech.
Having explained false speech, we will now explain the other three kinds of speech.
Verse:
Speech that harms others with a defiled mind is called divisive speech,
Unpleasant and coarse speech, all defiled and mixed speech,
Others say it is different from the three defiled, such as flattery, singing, and wrong theories, etc.
Discussion:
If defiled mind issues forth speech that destroys another, whether the other is destroyed or not, both constitute divisive speech.
Understanding the meaning and not being mistaken are included here.
If with a defiled mind one utters unpleasant speech to defame another, this is called coarse and evil speech.
The previous defiled mind speech flows to this point, so understanding the meaning and not being mistaken are also the same as before.
All the various speech issued forth by a defiled mind is called mixed and defiled speech, because it is all mixed and defiled.
Only the previous word speech flows to this point.
Some say that apart from the previous three, the other defiled mind speech, such as flattery, singing, and false doctrines, is only included in mixed and defiled speech.
Flattery refers to bhiká¹£us seeking fame and profit through flattery and loving speech.
Singing refers to actors and entertainers delighting others with a defiled mind and engaging in various flattery and singing to each other.
False doctrines refer to the doctrines of SÄá¹ƒkhya and so on, and the words describing evil views, such as the defiled mind issuing forth lamentations and frivolous discourses.
When a wheel-turning king appears in the world, singing and other speech accords with liberation and is contrary to defilement, so they are all not included in frivolous speech.

Some say that when there is marriage and other speech, it is included in frivolous speech, but not included in the karmic paths, because it is of a weak defilement class and does not attract unmanifest [karma]. It is not that there is no unmanifest [karma] that can be included in the karmic paths.
Having explained the three types of speech, we will now explain the three of mind.
Verse:
Covetousness, ill-will, and wrong views are the three karmic paths of mind.
Treatise:
Unreasonably coveting other people's property, wishing to make it one's own, either by force or stealth, such evil desire is called the karmic path of covetousness.
Giving rise to a mind of hatred and resentment towards sentient beings, wishing to oppress them, is called the karmic path of ill-will.
Denying the existence of good, evil, and so forth, this view is called the karmic path of wrong views.
Mentioning the first includes the later, thus the word and so forth is used.
If we were to explain them in full, we would have to explain them as the sutras do, that is, as eleven kinds of wrong views, such as denying causes and denying results, and so on.
We have now explained the characteristics of the ten kinds of paths of action.
On the basis of what meaning are the paths of action established?
A verse says:
Among them, the last three are only paths, and the first seven are both action and paths.
The treatise says:
Among the ten paths of action, the last three are only paths, because they are the paths of action, and therefore they are established as paths of action.
The volition associated with them is called action, because it turns due to them, it proceeds due to them, and it is produced by their power.
The first seven are action, because they are bodily and verbal action;
they are also the paths of action, because volition moves along them.
Because the volition that generates bodily and verbal action turns due to having bodily and verbal action as its object.
Action is the path of action, and therefore it is established as a path of action.

Therefore, in this context, the term â€œpath of actionâ€ fully reveals the meaning of both â€œpath of actionâ€ and â€œaction that is a path of action.â€ Although they are not of the same type, one is used for the other, because they are both well established in the treatises on worldly matters.
Alternatively, it is called a â€œpath of actionâ€ because it is the path of action, and it is also called a â€œpath of actionâ€ because it is both action and a path.
It should be fully said to be a â€œpath of action that is a path of action,â€ but because one is used for the other, it is simply called a â€œpath of action.â€
The meaning of a â€œgood path of actionâ€ should be understood in the same way.
The preparatory and subsequent actions should be called â€œpaths of action,â€ because volition also occurs taking them as objects.

Although it should be explained in this way, it is not explained. This is because they occur based on the fundamental path of action, because the coarse fundamental path of action is explained first, and because the internal and external increase and decrease follow the fundamental path of action.
All evil paths of action manifest in opposition to good, and they sever the roots of good.
By what path of action are the roots of good severed?
What is the distinction?
The verse states:
Only wrong views can sever good roots, which are severed in the desire realm and are acquired at birth.
Eliminating cause and effect, all, gradually severing two, both abandoned.
Humans in three continents, men and women, seeing practice, severing non-attainment,
Continuing goodness, doubting existence, views, suddenly manifesting, excluding those who violate the precepts.
The treatise says:
Among the evil karmic paths, only the highest and most perfect wrong views can sever the roots of goodness.
If so, why does the original treatise say:
What are the highest roots of non-goodness?
It refers to the roots of non-goodness that can sever the roots of goodness, or those first eliminated in the state of detachment.

Because the roots of non-goodness can lead to wrong views, the matter of wrong views is attributed to those roots, just as fire burns a village, and the fire starts because of thieves, so the world says the village was burned by thieves.
What roots of goodness are severed by this?
It refers only to the roots of goodness obtained through birth in the desire realm, because the goodness of the form and formless realms has not yet been accomplished.

Why is it that only the innate roots of goodness are severed?
Because the roots of goodness that are acquired through effort have already been lost.
What causes the severing of the roots of goodness, and in what states of consciousness?

There is a class of persons who have a disposition to form the most extremely evil thoughts and intentions. Later, when they encounter evil friends and the power of conditions, they become even more violent, and thus the roots of goodness decrease and the roots of evil increase.

Later, they give rise to wrong views that deny causes and deny results, and all the roots of goodness are completely destroyed. As a result, the continuity of their lives is devoid of roots of goodness.

The wrong views that sever the roots of goodness in this state of mind have two kinds: those that take as their objects only the realm in which the person is born and those that take as their objects other realms, and those that take as their objects only contaminated dharmas and those that take as their objects both contaminated and uncontaminated dharmas.
Who can sever the roots of goodness?
It should be said that all sentient beings can sever the roots of goodness.

How is it?

That is, one gradually eliminates the nine grades of wrong views and the nine grades of wholesome roots, which are eliminated in sequence, like the elimination of the afflictions to be eliminated by cultivation in the path of cultivation.
Since it is like the elimination of the afflictions to be eliminated by the path of cultivation, it is reasonable that one may or may not pass through the intermediate stages.
The fruits of the disciplines arise from either the wholesome mind of added effort or the wholesome mind of birth, and one abandons them when one abandons their causes.
In what places can one cut off the wholesome roots?
In the three continents of the human realm, not in the evil destinies, because the wisdom of defilement and nondefilement is not firm.
Also not in the heavens, because one directly perceives the fruits of good and evil actions.
As for the three continents, it excludes the continent of Uttarakuru, because there is no extreme evil intention there.
In what kind of body does one cut off the wholesome roots in this way?
Only in the bodies of men and women, because their intentions are firm.
In what kind of practitioner can one cut off the wholesome roots?
Only in the practitioner of views, not in the practitioner of passion.
Because the evil intentions of those who practice views are extremely firm and deep.
Because the evil intentions of those who practice craving are extremely agitated.
For this reason, eunuchs and so on are excluded.
Also, because these kinds of people are like those in the evil destinies.
What is the substance of the severing of these roots of goodness?

It should be understood that the severing of goodness takes nonacquisition as its substance, because when the most serious wrong views are present, they cause the attainment of the roots of goodness to cease and the nonattainment to continue to arise. Therefore the substance of the severed roots of goodness is nonacquisition.
We have already established that nonacquisition really exists. By what means does the continuity of the roots of goodness resume after they have been severed?
It resumes through doubt and the view of existence.

That is, when one resumes the roots of goodness, either by the power of causes or by relying on a good friend, one suddenly gives rise to doubt concerning cause and effect, wondering whether or not there is an afterlife.

There are those who suddenly generate right views regarding cause and effect, definitely knowing there is an afterlife. Previously holding these views as wrong, at that time they accomplish the attainment of wholesome roots, and the attainment of non-accomplishment ceases, called the continuation of wholesome roots.
The nine grades of wholesome roots are suddenly continued but gradually arise, like suddenly curing an illness but gradually increasing strength. Can one continue wholesome roots in the present body?
There are those who can continue, except for those who commit the five heinous crimes.

How many of the good and evil paths of action arise simultaneously with thought?
A verse says:
The paths of action arise simultaneously with thought, from one up to eight,
In the case of good, generally up to ten, but specifically, blocking one, eight, or five.
The treatise says:
As for the simultaneous occurrence of volition with the karmic paths, in the case of unwholesomeness and volition, it ranges from one to eight.
One simultaneous occurrence means that, excluding the rest, any one of the three such as greed arises.
If the evil karma created by prior preparatory effort is present, and the mind is defiled by greed or other defilements, or is undefiled, then one [of the three such as greed] is completed.
Two simultaneous occurrences means engaging in sexual misconduct.
If one personally commits killing, stealing, or frivolous speech, or sends someone else to do it, then one of them is established, and any one of greed, hatred, or wrong views is present.
If the evil karma created by prior preparatory effort is present, and the mind is defiled by greed or other defilements, or is undefiled, then two [of the three such as greed] are completed.

Three simultaneous occurrences means that if the evil karma created by prior preparatory effort arises, and the mind is defiled by greed or other defilements, then three [of the three such as greed] are completed.
If one sends a messenger to commit one of killing, etc., and personally engages in sexual misconduct, etc., they are completed simultaneously.
If one personally commits two [of the three such as killing], one should consider it accordingly.
If one performs evil actions through prior effort, and then, with a mind of greed or other defilement or an undefiled mind, one completes the three actions,
if one arouses greed or other defilement, it is included in the action itself.
If one causes others to do divisive speech, false speech, or harsh speech, one should contemplate in the same way according to reason.
Four simultaneous actions means that if one utters false speech or harsh speech in order to destroy others, there is one mental action and three verbal actions.

If one sends two messengers and oneself engages in sexual misconduct, or if one performs evil actions through prior effort, and then, when greed or other defilements arise, completes the three actions,
one should contemplate in the same way according to reason.
Five, six, and seven simultaneous actions should be explained according to reason.
Eight simultaneous actions means that if one performs the six evil actions through prior effort, and oneself engages in sexual misconduct, they are completed simultaneously.
One should contemplate in the same way according to reason.
The last three cannot be simultaneous, so there are no nine or ten.
The unwholesome courses of action have been explained like this.
The number of these that occur simultaneously with volition varies. In general, up to ten may occur simultaneously with wholesome volition, but in specific cases, only one, eight, or five may occur.

Two may occur simultaneously with volition, namely, the five consciousnesses and the consciousnesses of the stages of exhaustion and nonproduction of the four truths, which are wholesome but not the seven good mental activities. The discernment associated with these is not insight by nature, and there is no morality associated with the formless realm.
Three may occur simultaneously with volition, namely, when the attention associated with right views is present, but the seven good mental activities are absent.
Four may occur simultaneously with volition, namely, when a mind of evil or indeterminate character is present, and one acquires the morality of the devotee, the novice, or the full monk.
Six may occur simultaneously with volition, namely, when the five consciousnesses are good, and one acquires the three kinds of morality.
Seven may occur simultaneously with volition, namely, when good volition of the stage of manas is present, unaccompanied by the activities of thought, and one acquires the three kinds of morality.
Or, when a mind of evil or indeterminate character is present, and one acquires the morality of the full monk.
